name.paramonov.doomep.shogi

Class Piece

  • java.lang.Object
    • name.paramonov.doomep.shogi.Piece
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    EmptyPiece, Pawn

    public abstract class Piece
extends java.lang.Object
    A Class representing a piece in a game of shogi. This class defines the basic requirements for a piece:
    • Has a given location.
    • Has an allegiance to a side.
    • Is promoted.
    • Is located on the board or on in the drop table.
    All pieces extend this class, and implement different rules of checking for valid moves and promotion.

    • Field Detail

      • STARTING_BOARD_Y

        protected static final int STARTING_BOARD_Y
        The y-value of the first row on the board. Used before the starting board value is finalized.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • x

        protected int x
        The x-value of this piece on the gameboard. Will be in a range from 1 to 9.

      • y

        protected int y
        The y-value of this piece on the gameboard. Will be in a range from 1 to 9.

      • allegiance

        protected int allegiance
        This piece's allegiance. Equivalent to a piece's color in chess. The side that this piece belongs to. Possible values are:
        • 1: "White" (Bottom side).
        • 0: "Mercenary" (Neutral).
        • -1: "Black" (Top side).
        Mercenary pieces can be captured by either side, and then dropped. They do not move, and cannot attack any pieces.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Piece

        public Piece()

    • Method Detail

      • checkMove

        public abstract boolean checkMove(java.util.List<java.util.List<Piece>> board,
                int x,
                int y)
        Returns whether a move can be undertaken by this Piece. Each piece has different rules, so this one is to be implemented individually.
        Parameters:
        board - The current state of the board at the time of verification.
        x - The x-value to which this piece is trying to move.
        y - The y-value to which this piece is trying to move.
        Returns:
        Whether this Piece can move to the given x and y values.

      • move

        public abstract java.util.List<java.util.List<Piece>> move(java.util.List<java.util.List<Piece>> board,
                                         int x,
                                         int y)
        Moves this piece to a different location. Changes the x and y-values of this Piece, and then returns a board style List<List<Piece>>
        Parameters:
        board - The currect state of the board at the time of this method being run.
        x - The x-value to which this piece is trying to move.
        y - The y-value to which this piece is trying to move.
        Returns:
        The state of the board after this piece has been moved.

      • getPromotable

        public abstract boolean getPromotable()
        Verifies whether this piece can be promoted. This is placed here so that calling .getPromotable() can be done on any piece, which allows us to find out exactly which pieces can be promoted. If it was implemented in a different class, that would cause trouble if we were to verify for any piece.
        Returns:
        Whether or not the piece can be promoted.

      • promote

        public abstract Piece promote()
        Returns the piece this piece is promoted to. Each piece promotes to a different piece, and therefore is implemented individually in each subclass.
        Returns:
        The piece this piece promotes to.

      • getX

        public int getX()
        Returns this piece's x-value.
        Returns:
        This piece's x location on the board.

      • getY

        public int getY()
        Returns this piece's y-value.
        Returns:
        This piece's y location on the board.

      • getAllegiance

        public int getAllegiance()
        Returns this piece's allegiance. Possible values are:
        • 1: "White" (Bottom side).
        • 0: "Mercenary" (Neutral).
        • -1: "Black" (Top side).
        Mercenary pieces can be captured by either side, and then dropped. They do not move, and cannot attack any pieces.
        Returns:
        The value of this piece's allegiance.

      • setAllegiance

        public int setAllegiance(int allegiance)
        Sets this piece's allegiance. Use for capturing pieces. Possible values listed above. Method has a return in order to double-check whether the setting worked flawlessly.
        Returns:
        The new value of this piece's allegiance.
